questions.text: The sonography demonstrates:
questions.solution:
The given ultrasonograph demonstrates overlapping skull bones, also known as Spalding sign. 

Option A: Spalding sign

  • The irregular overlapping of cranial bones on one another is due to liquefaction of brain and softening of ligamentous structures supporting the vault.
  • It usually appears 7 days after death

Option B: Roberts sign

  • Earliest sign of IUD - seen within 12 hours of death
  • The presence of gas shadow within the chambers of the heart and in large vessels of the fetus.

Option C: Blair-Hartley/Ball: sign 

  • Hyperextension/hyperflexion of spine with crowding of ribs
  • Usually seen 3-4 weeks after death
Sign Interval (After Death)
Robert sign (gas in great vessels) 12h
Spalding sign (overlapping of skull bones) 1 week
Blair-Hartley / Ball sign (hyperflexion / hyperextension of spine over ovecrowding of ribs) 3-4 weeks

questions.text: Unassisted(mature) pincer grasp is attained by the age of
questions.solution:
Related Pearl: Developmental progression of the grasp

Ulnar palmar grasp

6 months: object is grasped by the ulnar side of the palm   


Radial palmar grasp

8-9 months: object is grasped by the radial side of the palm    

 

Immature pincer grasp

9 months: the object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger 

 

Mature pincer grasp

12 months: the object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause intravascular hemolysis?
questions.solution:
Thalassemia causes extravascular hemolysis.

Causes of intravascular hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura ) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn 
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - Clostridial sepsis

Causes of extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anaemia

Causes of both intravascular and extravascular:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascularhemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura)
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility
    • Transfusion reaction
    • Drug-induced
  • Infectionsof red blood cells
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors- clostridialsepsis

Extravascularhemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Bothintravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient with sickle cell anaemia presents with fever and malaise. IgM ELISA confirms a parvovirus B19 infection. Which of the following crises will you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
Aplastic crisis in sickle cell anaemia is caused by parvovirus B19. It is a transient arrest of erythropoiesis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection. Parvovirus infects and kills red cell precursors. It occurs in sickle cell disease and other hemolytic anaemias.

Vaso-occlusive crises (pain crises) are episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severe pain in the affected region. The most commonly involved sites are the bones, lungs, liver, brain, spleen, and penis. Acute chest syndrome is a type of vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs. It typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Pulmonary inflammation may cause blood flow to become sluggish and “spleenlike,” leading to sickling and vaso-occlusion. 

Sequestration crises occur in children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cells leads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock. Both sequestration crises and acute chest syndrome may be fatal and sometimes require prompt treatment with exchange transfusions.

questions.text: A farmer from Hoshiarpur, Punjab rushes his 10-year-old boy to the paediatric ER. The father complained of intractable nausea and diarrhoea in the child. On examination, the child has a garlicky odour and is severely dehydrated.  You notice neurologic manifestations along with nail and hair changes in the child. Which of the following mineral toxicities would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of acute selenium toxicity.

Selenium toxicity is characterised by nausea, diarrhoea, neurologic manifestations, nail and hair changes, and garlicky odour. It is commonly seen in areas where drinking water and the collated soil is extremely rich in selenium. In India, selenium toxicity is endemic to agricultural sites located in the states of Punjab and Haryana. The presentations are usually acute in nature rather than chronic. 

Chromium toxicity (Option - B) is commonly seen only in adults with occupational exposure. Chromium is a pulmonary irritant and the symptoms are predominantly respiratory complaints similar to bronchitis. They also cause chronic allergic dermatitis and is carcinogenic too. 

Molybdenum toxicity (Option C) is very rarely seen in humans. It manifests usually as acute diarrhoea. 

Iodine toxicity (Option D) can range from mild GI illness to chronic thyroid dysfunction varying from hyperthyroidism to papillary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true with respect to the WHO Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative for small, sick, and preterm newborns (2020)?

choices.text: Paladai feeding is indicated in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breath coordination
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge
Feeding tubes are indicated only in neurologically compromised infants for long-term use
Bottle feeding can lead to overfeeding but has a reduced risk of aspiration in infants with immature suck-swallow-breathe reflex

questions.solution:
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge. It is indicated in neurologically compromised and preterm infants for a short period of time. 

Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm, late preterm, and term infants for supplementation. It is economic, cheap, and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method of feeding. 

Feeding tubes- orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It is optimally used in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-term use. It requires frequent replacement.

Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teats mimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. They allow overfeeding and there is a risk of aspiration.

World Breastfeeding Week is a global campaign celebrated 1-7 August every year. World Breastfeeding Week aims to highlight the benefits that breastfeeding can bring to both the health and welfare of babies, as well as for maternal health. The theme for the year 2022 is "Step Up for Breastfeeding: Educate and Support".

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common trigger for hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency?
questions.solution:
The most common trigger for hemolysis in G6PD deficiency isinfection.Viral hepatitis, pneumonia, and typhoid are the common infections that trigger hemolysis.

Episodic hemolysis (both intravascular and extravascular) is seen in G6PD deficiency. It is due to exposures that cause oxidative stress. The triggers include:

  • Infections - oxygen-derived free radicals produced by activated leukocytes
  • Drugs
    • Antimalarials -primaquine and chloroquine
    • Sulfonamides
    • Nitrofurantoin
  • Diet - fava bean

questions.text: Complications of placenta previa include all except
questions.solution:
Complication of placenta previa
Antepartum:
o Malpresentation
o Cord prolapse
o Premature labor
o Early rupture of membranes
Intrapartum:
o Slow dilation of cervix
o Intrapartum hemorrhage
o Increased incidence of operative interference
Postpartum:
o Post partum hemorrhage
o Retained placenta

questions.text: The following image shows the chest X-ray of a preterm neonate who was admitted to the NICU in view of severe respiratory distress.  What does this suggest?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture of respiratory distress in a premature neonate and the X-ray findings of diffuse ground-glass (reticulo-granular) opacities with a characteristic white-out appearance, hyaline membrane disease (HMD) is the most likely diagnosis.

HMD, also known as neonatal Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is a relatively common condition resulting from insufficient production of surfactant that occurs in preterm neonates. Maternal diabetes, perinatal asphyxia, and multiple gestations are other known risk factors for the condition. Clinical features include tachypnea, chest retractions, expiratory grunting, and nasal flaring. The infant may or may not be cyanosed. 

X-ray features of HMD include:

  • Air bronchogram sign
  • Diffuse ground-glass opacities
  • Obliteration of cardiac and diaphragmatic contours giving rise to 'white-out' lung (indicates severe disease)

 

Chest radiograph (A) shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

questions.text: Hunterian chancre is caused by

questions.text: A diabetic patient who has developed chronic renal failure is prescribed a dipeptidyl-peptidase 4 (DPP4) inhibitor. No dose adjustment was done. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to him?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the drug that was most likely prescribed to this patient islinagliptin. It is a DPP-4 inhibitor thatcan be safely used in renal failure.It is mainly excreted through the hepatobiliary route.

DPP4 inhibitors are orally acting novel drugs that act by the incretin pathway and stimulate insulin secretion. These drugs have significantly lesser chances of hypoglycemic side effects. These drugs are mainly eliminated unchanged by the kidneys, exceptLinagliptin which is eliminated by the hepatobiliary route and is therefore considered relatively safer in a patient with renal failure.

Other options:

Option A: Dulaglutide is safe in renal failure, but it is aGLP-1 analog.

Option B: Vildagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor but is excreted in the urine. The dose should be decreased in patients with renal failure.

Option D: Pramlintide is anamylin analog andcan be used in moderate renal disease.

questions.text: In rugoscopy identification of a person is performed by taking prints from which part of hard palate
questions.solution:

  • Chelioscopy is the study of lip prints
  • Podogram is the study of foot prints
  • Ear prints and nose prints are also used for identification

questions.text: MAC value of an inhaled anesthetic is a measure of?
questions.solution:
• Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhaled anesthetic is the amount which is required to prevent movement in response to a defined noxious stimulus in 50% of subjects.
  • MAC is a useful measure which allows comparisons of Potency between agents.
  • Lower the MAC value, lower is the concentration of anesthetic drug required which would imply the drug is more potent.
  • Example: Nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104 is the least potent inhaled anesthetic.
    Methoxy flurane – MAC- 0.2, most potent.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a natural Uncoupler?
questions.solution:
• Uncouplers act by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane to ions, thereby collapsing the proton gradient established by allowing the H+ to pass across without going through the ATP synthase enzyme complex. This is how these substances ‘uncouple’ electron flow through the respiratory complexes from ATP synthesis.
  • Examples of Uncouplers:
    1. Synthetic – 2, 4 dinitrophenol
    2. Natural – Thermogenin: This is found naturally in the brown adipose tissue, whose function is heat generation, especially in new born.
  • Oligomycin is a competitive inhibitor of the Fo complex. By binding to the Fo domain of ATP synthase it closes the proton channel and hence prevents the reentry of protons into the matrix. By doing so, it stops the phosphorylation of ADP to ATP. It basically blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by stopping the flow of protons through ATP synthase enzyme complex.
  • Atractyloside is an inhibitor of oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Inhibitors of ETC
COMPLEX INHIBITORS
Complex I Rotenone, Amobarbital and Piercidin A
Complex II TTFA, Carboxin and Malonate
Complex III Antimycin A and BAL
Complex IV Carbon monoxide, H2S, Cyanide and Sodium Azide

questions.text: False regarding mirror syndrome
questions.solution:
Mirror Syndrome
An association between fetal hydrops and development of maternal edema in which the fetus mirrors the mother is attributed to Ballantyne. He called the condition triple edema because the fetus, mother, and placenta all became edematous. In a review case of mirror syndrome, it is found that approximately.

  • 90 percent of women had edema
  • 60 percent had hypertension,
  • 40 percent had proteinuria,
  • 20 percent had liver enzyme elevation, and
  • Nearly 15 percent had a headache and visual disturbances.

Based on these findings, it is reasonable to consider mirror syndrome a form of severe preeclampsia.

questions.text: True statement regarding inverse agonist is

choices.text: Binds to the receptor and causes intended action
Binds to the receptor and causes opposite action
Binds to the receptor and causes no action
Binds to the receptor and causes submaximal action

questions.solution:
• According to the receptor occupation theory, the ability of a drug to bind to a receptor is its affinity and the ability to induce functional change in the receptor is designated as the intrinsic activity (IA) of the drug. These 2 properties are independent of each other. IA can be between -1 to +1.
  • Inverse agonists are drugs which have affinity for a receptor but the intrinsic activity opposite to that of an agonist i.e IA of an inverse agonist is -1.
  • Agonists: these have both affinity and IA of +1.
  • Partial agonists: have affinity but submaximal intrinsic activity. e.g pentazocine on µ opiod receptors.
  • Competitive Antagonists: have affinity but intrinsic activity 0.

questions.text: The ECG given below is seen in which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
The blue arrows in the above ECG point to the J wave or the Osborn wave or the camel hump waves. This wave is seen in Hypothermia.

Option B: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.

Option C: STEMI shows ST segment elevation not J wave elevation on ECG.

Option D: U waves are seen in hypokalemia.

questions.text: An old cab driver whose livelihood depends on his driving is distressed. He complains that everything appears distorted and he perceives objects to smaller than their usual size. His anterior segment appears normal. Examination of the fundus reveals a honeycomb appearance of the macula. FFA is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is that of fluorescein angiography showing the "flower petal pattern,"which is seen in cystoid macular edema (CME). The characteristic flower-petal appearance is due to the accumulation of dye in the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer at the macula

The accumulation of fluid in the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer leads to retinal thickening at macula and loss of foveal depression, formation of cystic spaces (honey-comb macula). Risk factors include retinitis pigmentosa, uveitis, niacin, PGE2 analogues, epinephrine in aphakia, diabetic retinopathy, retinal venous occlusion and Irvin-Gass syndrome (CME post-cataract surgery).

Symptoms may include blurring of vision, distortion, and micropsia.

Therapeutic approaches for treating CME depend on the underlying etiology. This includes steroids, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, anti-VEGF agents, PPV for associated vitreomacular traction.

questions.text: Von Gierkes disease is due to deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
• Von Gierkes is a glycogen storage disorder which is caused due to deficiency of Glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme.
  • The structural gene for glucose-6-phosphatase is located on chromosome 17. Von-Gierkes disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.
  • The biochemical hallmarks of the Von Gierke’s disease are:
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Lactic acidosis
    • Hyperuricemia
    • Hyperlipidemia

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal colic and constipation. On examination, pallor and blue stippled lines on gums are observed. What is the most common mode of exposure to this particular toxicity?
questions.solution:
A patient presenting with constipation, pallor, and Burton's lines (blue stippled lines on gums), most likely has lead poisoning. The most common mode of exposure to lead toxicity is the inhalation of lead fumes. 

Lead poisoning occurs by lead exposure via the following modes:

  • Inhalation- lead fumes in gasoline and petroleum products
  • Ingestion- lead paint
  • Absorption through the skin– seen only with organic leads

The most toxic forms of lead are lead oxide, lead carbonate, and lead arsenate. The least toxic form is lead sulfide.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy-Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: False statement about methotrexate
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is an inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFRase). It also inhibits thymidylate synthase.

Uses of methotrexate:

  • Immunosuppressant
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • DOC for choriocarcinoma
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (anti-inflammatory)
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis
  • Osteosarcoma


Adverse effects:

  • Hepatotoxic
  • Nephrotoxic
  • Mucositis
  • Diarrhoea
  • Bone marrow suppression
  • Pulmonary fibrosis


• Toxicity of methotrexate to normal cells can be reduced by administration of folinic acid or leucovorin or citrovorum factor.

questions.text: Sputum smear becomes positive on ZN staining when the concentration of TB bacillus in the sample are more than
questions.solution:
For the sputum sample to become positive on ZN staining there must be a minimum of 10000 Bacilli/ml. On ZN staining the decolorizer used is 25% is sulphuric acid, bacilli appear rod shaped with beaded appearance (which is due to mycolic acid in the cell wall)

Grading of smears on ZN stain

0 No Bacilli/100 oil immersion fields
Scanty 1-9 Bacilli /100 oil immersion fields
1+ 10-99 Bacilli /100 oil immersion fields
2+ 1-10 Bacilli /oil immersion field
3+ >10 Bacilli /oil immersion field

questions.solution:
5 day fever or trench fever is casued by B.quintana

• It can grow in a cell free culture media such as blood agar

Diseases transmitted by louse include

  • Epidemic typhus
  • Trench fever/ 5 day fever
  • Epidemic relapsing fever
  • Pediculosis

questions.text: In a negatively skewed distribution, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
In negatively skewed distribution Mean<Median<Mode.

The normal distribution curve is a symmetric curve, also called the Bell curve. In the normal distribution curve, the mean = median = mode. The distribution can be skewed due to either abnormally low or abnormally high values. There are two types of skewing

  • Negative or left skewed: Mean < Median < Mode
  • Positive or right skewed: Mean > Median > Mode

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median 2 mean (or) Mean = (3 median mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is themedian.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: All of the following are true about HMG coA reductase inhibitors except

choices.text: CNS accumulation of simvastatin and lovastatin is high and less for pravastatin and fluvastatin
Simvastatin is rapidly metabolised and pravastatin is least metabolised
Bioavailability is minimally modified when pravastatin is taken with food
Fibrinogen levels are increased by pravastatin

questions.solution:
• Fibrinogen levels are decreased by pravastatin not increased.
  • Among the statins Pravastatin has got some special features.
    Pravastatin:
  • Minimum drug interactions (not metabolized by microsomal enzymes)
  • Minimum food interactions (absorption of all other statins are increased by food)
  • Minimum risk of myopathy
  • Minimum CNS penetration
  • Minimize (decrease) fibrinogen level

questions.text: Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is seen in
questions.solution:
Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is seen in premenopausal females. ILD (Interstitial lung disease), in general, occur more commonly in women.


               Gender predisposition in ILDs

Women Men
Exclusively in premenopausal women:LAM Pulmonary involvement in Tuberous Sclerosis Pneumoconiosis (due to occupational exposure to asbestos, beryllium, and silica)
ILDs in association with CTD(connective tissue disorder) (except ILD is associated with rheumatoid arthritis) ILD is associated with rheumatoid arthritis 
  IPF (Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis)
  Pulmonary LCH (Langerhans cell histiocytosis)

Lymphangioleiomyomatosis

Seen in young women with recurrent pneumothorax or chylous effusion. The disease accelerates during pregnancy and abates after oophorectomy. HRCT shows thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma. It is associated with meningioma. Marker: HMB-45.

questions.text: Secretion of casein by mammary gland cells is an example of

• Mammary gland cells secrete  milk protein, casein, by merocrine secretion.
  • Milk fat is secreted by apocrine secretion
  • In merocrine secretion, secretions are initially packaged into membrane-bound vesicles which then fuse with the plasma membrane to release their contents to the exterior. It is by far the most common secretory mechanism.
  • In apocrine glands, some of the apical cytoplasm is pinched off with the contained secretions, which are stored in the cell as membrane-free droplets.
  • In holocrine glands, cells first fill with secretory products, after which the entire cell disintegrates to liberate the accumulated mass of secretion into the adjacent duct.
  • Glands such as simple sweat glands of skin, where ions and water are actively transported from plasma as an exudate, were once classified as eccrine glands. They are now known to synthesize and secrete small amounts of protein by a merocrine mechanism, and have been reclassified as merocrine glands.
  • Type of Gland and location:
    Apocrine glands  Secretion of milk fat by mammary gland cells, specialized sweat glands in the axilla and anogenital regions of the body. 
    Merocrine glands  Secretion of milk protein, sweat glands previously classified as eccrine glands 
    Holocrine glands  sebaceous glands in the skin

questions.text: All of the following drugs are used for chronic prophylaxis of migraine except:
questions.solution:
Sumatriptan has no role in the chronic prophylaxis of migraine. It is only used for the treatment of an acute episode.

Medication for chronic prophylaxis of migraine should be considered in patients with four or more attacks per month. The medications that are beneficial include:

  • Beta-blockers: propranolol, metoprolol
  • Anti-depressants: amitriptyline, venlafaxine
  • Anti-convulsants: valproate, topiramate
  • CGRP antagonists (monoclonal antibodies): eptinezumab, erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab
  • Others: flunarizine, candesartan, memantine

Migraine is a primary headache disorder characterized by episodic headaches. The patients present with a unilateral, throbbing type of headache. The headache is preceded by a prodrome period characterized by mental fatigue, mood changes, and aura in the form of visual disturbances (zigzag lines in the visual field). The headache is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

Acute treatment of migraine is done with paracetamol and NSAIDs (naproxen, diclofenac). If this treatment does not bring relief, triptans such as sumatriptan or rizatriptan are given. They are agonists at 5HT1B/1D receptors and cause vasoconstriction in the intracranial blood vessels. Other drugs that can be given for the acute treatment of migraine are calcitonin-gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonists rimegepant and ubrogepant.

questions.text: Injury to median nerve at the wrist is tested by

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the palm
Loss of sensation on the ring finger

questions.solution:
• Abductor pollicis brevis is the one small muscle of the hand that is consistently innervated by the median nerve.
  • Flexor pollicis brevis cannot be tested separately as flexion of MCP joint can be produced by FPL as well.
  • Sensation of lateral aspect of palm by palmar cutaneous branch is given in distal forearm, hence spared by injury at the wrist.
  • Ring finger has sensory supply from median and ulnar nerve.

questions.text: Primordial germ cells are derived from
questions.solution: Primordial germ cells are derived from theepiblast/ primitive ectoderm in the 2ndweek of Intrauterine life.

questions.text: ANCA positivity is seen in
questions.solution:
ANCA (Antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody) positivity is seen in certain types of vasculitis. There are 2 types: c ANCA and p ANCA                                                          

  c ANCA p ANCA
Location of ANCA Cytoplasmic Perinuclear
Target antigen Proteinase 3 Myeloperoxidase
Positive in: Wegener’s granulomatosis(Granulomatosis with polyangiitis) Microscopic polyangiitisChurg-Strauss syndrome

questions.text: Mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres and megacolon are conditions associated with which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
MEN 2B is also called MEN 3. It arises from a mutation in RET protoncogene and is characterized by:
• Medullary thyroid cancer (>90%)
• Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
• Associated abnormalities;
• Mucosal neuromas
• Marfanoid habitus
• Medullated corneal nerve fibres
• Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition. The biopsy on the frozen section is given below. All of the following are true about this carcinoma, except that _____.

choices.text: It is associated with RAS mutation.
It usually presents as solitary nodule.
It can be diagnosed by FNAC.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient from a hillyarea (iodine-deficient) and the biopsy specimen showing capsular invasion by tumor follicles confirms the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma. Follicular carcinoma cannot be diagnosed by FNAC.

FNAC cannot distinguish between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma. Capsular invasion must be present to diagnose follicular carcinoma, which can be seen only on biopsy.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: All the following are seen in ADHD except?
questions.solution:
ADHD – Attention deficit hyperactive disorder.Is the most common psychiatric problem in school going age group. It is more common in boys than in girls. It is characterized by hyperactivity, impulsiveness and inattention. ADHD In children can lead to anti-social behaviour in the later ages.
Attention deficit hyperactive disorder

Diagnostic criteria:

6 of the inattention symptoms for 6 months

  • Makes careless mistakes
  • Difficulty in maintaining attention
  • Do not listen
  • Fails to follow instructions
  • Avoids tasks and difficulty in organizing tasks
  • Easily distracted and forgetful

6 or more symptoms of hyperactivity

  • Leaves seat
  • Difficulty in playing and talks excessively

Symptoms of impulsivity

  • Difficulty awaiting turn
  • Often interrupts

Treatment for ADHD
The first line treatment is pharmacotherapy
a. CNS stimulants – methylphenidate, other drugs are- modafinil, atomoxetine, bupropion
b. Behavioral treatment and psychological treatment is given

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common neoplasm of salivary gland?
questions.solution:
• MC neoplasm of salivary gland : Pleomorphic adenoma
  • MC neoplasm of salivary gland in children : Hemangioma
  • MC malignant tumour of salivary gland : Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • MC malignant tumour of salivary gland in children : Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • MC malignant tumour of minor salivary glands : Adenoid cystic carcinoma

questions.text: Primary peritonitis with pneumococcus is associated with which of the following
questions.solution:
• Primary pneumococcal peritonitis may complicate nephrotic syndrome or cirrhosis in children.
  • Otherwise healthy children particularly girls between 3-9 years may also be affected, route of infection is via vagina and fallopian tubes.
  • Always in males, infection is blood-borne and secondary to respiratory tract or middle ear disease.
    Clinical features:
  • Sudden onset pain in lower abdomen.
  • Temperature as high as 39 degrees celsius or higher.
  • After 1-2 days, profuse diarrhoea, increased frequency of micturition (due to severe pelvic peritonitis)
  • On examination, abdominal rigidity
    Diagnosis:
  • WBC count more than 30,000/microlitre with approximately 90% polymorphs suggests pneumococcal peritonitis.
  • If exudate is odourless and sticky, the diagnosis of pneumcoccal peritonitis is certain
    Treatment:
  • Antibiotic treatment + correcting dehydration and electrolyte imbalance+ early surgery
  • laparotomy or laparoscopy

questions.text: GH is produced by which cells of pituitary?
questions.solution:
GH is produced by acidophil Five types of secretory cells have been identified in the anterior pituitary by immunocytochemistry and electron microscopy. The cell types are

•    The somatotropes, which secrete growth hormone;

•    The lactotropes (also called mammotropes), which secrete prolactin;

•    The corticotropes, which secrete ACTH;

•    The thyrotropes, which secrete TSH; and

•    The gonadotropes, which secrete FSH and LH.

Cell type Hormones Secreted % of total secretory cells
Somatotrope Growth hormone 50
Lactotrope Prolactin 10-30
Corticotrope ACTH 10
Thyrotrope TSH 5
Gonadotrope FSH, LH 20

Some cells may contain two or more hormones. It is also notable that the three pituitary glycoprotein hormones, FSH, LH, and TSH, while being made up of two subunits, all share a common α subunit that is the product of a single gene and has the same amino acid composition in each hormone, although their carbohydrate residues vary. The β subunits, which are produced by separate genes and differ in structure, confer hormonal specificity. Somatotropes and lactotrophs stain strongly with acid dyes and are therefore called acidophils. Thus, pituitary tumors that secrete large quantities of human growth hormone are called acidophilic tumors. The rest of the cells are basophils.

questions.text: Barton's fracture is

choices.text: Extra articular fracture distal end of radius
Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius
Intra- articular fracture of distal end of radius with carpal bone subluxation

questions.solution:
Bartons fracture is Intra- articular fracture of distal end of radius with carpal bone subluxation.

Mechanism Of Injury: fall on flexed wrist with dorsiflexion and pronation of distal forearm.


Clinical features:

  • Pain
  • Swelling
  • Tenderness
  • Restriction of wrist movements with painful dorsiflexion.

Radiograph:
Best seen on the lateral view, the dorsal tip of distal radial articular surface is displaced proximally and posteriorly and may be associated with dorsal subluxation of the wrist.

Treatment:

  • Conservative - short arm cast with the wrist in neutral position.
  • Surgery - unstable fracture is fixed by percutaneous pins or small screws. Open Reduction +Internal Fixation with small plate and screws can be done.

questions.text: The velocity of conduction of impulse is maximum in the?
questions.solution:
The velocity of conduction is maximum in the Purkinje fibers, which is 4 meters/sec. The table below shows the conduction velocities in different cardiac structures.  

Tissue Conduction rate(m/s)
SA node 0.05
Atrial pathways 1
AV node 0.05
Bundle of His 1
Purkinje system 4
Ventricular muscle 1

questions.text: In otosclerosis during stapes surgery prosthesis used is
questions.solution:
• Teflon piston is used as prosthesis for stapes in otosclerosis surgery.
  • Grommet insertion is required in serous otitis media.
  • Total ossicular replacement prosthesis (TORP) is used when it is required to reconstruct whole of the ossicular chain for example in unsafe CSOM when there occurs complete necrosis of all the three ossicles.

questions.text: Identify the below image
questions.solution:
The image depicts a bacterial corneal ulcer with hypopyon. The ulcer is round to oval in shape which is highly characteristic of the bacterial corneal ulcer. 

The organism causing the ulcer can only be confirmed by culture. In this question, only the image is provided. Hence, the best answer to this question is a bacterial corneal ulcer. Keratitis is inflammation of the cornea. Symptoms include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, blepharospasm, and varying degrees of diminution of vision. 

Bacterial keratitis

  • Fluorescein stains positive for ulcer
  • Sterile hypopyon.
  • Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Treatment of bacterial keratitis

  • Antibiotic eyedrops – broad-spectrum antibiotics
  • Antibiotic ointment at night
  • If not responding fortified antibiotic eyedrops are used Fortified cephazolin (5%), Fortified tobramycin (1.3%), Fortified vancomycin (5%)
  • Oral vit A and C- help in the healing of epithelium Systemic analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs.
 

Option B: Fungal corneal ulcer has feathery borders, satellite lesions, and necrotic slough.

Option C: Acanthamoeba keratitis shows irregularity and multifocal infiltration, pseudo dendrites, or elevated epithelial ridges.

Option D: Simplex keratitis shows a coarse punctate or stellate pattern of swollen opaque epithelial cells, a dendritic ulcer with terminal buds.

questions.text: Laryngeal crepitus is absent in all of the following except
questions.solution: Any condition behind the cricoid e.g. postcricoid malignancy or in front of the vertebra e.g. prevertebral or retropharyngeal abscess (hypo pharyngeal abscess) will lead to absent laryngeal crepitus.

questions.text: What is the principal antigen which is implicated in Pemphigus Vulgaris?
questions.solution: Pemphigus Vulgaris is an immunobullous disease or a chronic blistering disease which occurs due to an autoimmune process by the production of antibodies against desmosomes(adhesion proteins). In Pemphigus Vulgaris, desmoglein 3 is the principal antigen. Desmoglein 1 and Desmocollins are also implicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojna?
questions.solution:
In Rajiv Gandhi shramik kalyan yojna

  • The allowance is given at the rate of 50% of daily wage a maximum of 24 months.
  • This scheme provides unemployment allowance to those insured people who have been involuntarily thrown out of employment due to recession or retrenchment.
  • To qualify for the scheme the worker must have worked in that setup for 3 years or more.

Note: Park mentions 50% of daily wage for 6 months, the government has changed it to 24 months. Eligibility payment period has also been reduced period from 5 to 2 years.

questions.text: Bird beak appearance in barium swallow is seen in
questions.solution:
Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. The LES is hypertensive in about 50% of patients. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastro-esophageal junction (GEJ).

Radiographically, the esophagus is often dilated, and a standing column of contrast material is seen. Fixed, smooth narrowing is present in distal esophagus. Periodic relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter with continued drinking is a critical observation for distinguishing primary achalasia from pseudoachalasia—carcinoma of the gastroesophageal junction (a fixed, nonrelaxing obstruction).

The above image depicts a dilated esophagus with retained column of barium and “bird’s beaking” suggestive of achalasia.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows a Barium meal. (The condition depicted is trichobezoar which shows a filling defect in a barium meal X-ray)

Barium is used as a contrast for GI imaging.

Contraindications to use of Barium:

  • Tracheo esophageal fistula: Dianosil-water soluble non-ionic agent is used
  • Perforation peritonitis: Gastrograffin-Ionic water soluble agent is used

Procedures: For Single contrast films barium alone is used. Double contrast films requires air and barium which is better for small mucosal lesion.

  • Ba swallow uses barium paste (for esophagus)
  • Ba meal- 95% BaSO4 (for stomach and duodenum)
  • Ba meal follow through -50% BaSO4 (for small bowel)
  • Ba enema -25% BaSO4 (for large bowel)

Enteroclysis - gastrointestinal technique designed to provide improved evaluation of the small bowel from jejunum to ileocecal junction. It is done by intubating the jejunum and instillation of the contrast material through the tube.

The conventional fluoroscopic technique is not widely used since it is somewhat invasive, time and labour intensive, and not particularly pleasant for the patient. Modifications of the tradition technique may involve CT or MRI. It is indicated for examination of mucosal detail of the small intestine and improved evaluation of small bowel tumours or inflammatory disease.
